medical: PREOPERATIVE DIAGNOSIS: Umbilical hernia. POSTOPERATIVE DIAGNOSIS: Umbilical hernia. PROCEDURE PERFORMED: Repair of umbilical hernia. ANESTHESIA: General. COMPLICATIONS: None. ESTIMATED BLOOD LOSS: Minimal. PROCEDURE IN DETAIL: The patient was prepped and draped in the sterile fashion. An infraumbilical incision was formed and taken down to the fascia. The umbilical hernia carefully reduced back into the cavity, and the fascia was closed with interrupted vertical mattress sutures to approximate the fascia, and then the wounds were infiltrated with 0.25% Marcaine. The skin was reattached to the fascia with 2-0 Vicryls. The skin was approximated with 2-0 Vicryl subcutaneous and then 4-0 Monocryl subcuticular stitches, dressed with Steri-Strips and 4 x 4's. Patient was extubated and taken to the recovery area in stable condition.
layman:
PREOPERATIVE DIAGNOSIS: Umbilical hernia.  
POSTOPERATIVE DIAGNOSIS: Umbilical hernia.  
PROCEDURE PERFORMED: Repair of umbilical hernia.  
ANESTHESIA: General.  
COMPLICATIONS: None.  
ESTIMATED BLOOD LOSS: Minimal.  

PROCEDURE IN DETAIL: The patient was cleaned and covered with sterile drapes. A small cut was made below the belly button and cut down to the muscle layer. The hernia was gently pushed back into the belly cavity. The muscle layer was stitched together with vertical mattress stitches. The area was then numbed with a local anesthetic (0.25% Marcaine). The skin was sewn to the muscle layer with 2‑0 Vicryl stitches. The skin was closed with 2‑0 Vicryl stitches under the skin and 4‑0 Monocryl stitches on the surface. The wound was covered with Steri‑Strips and a 4 × 4 dressing. The patient was taken off the breathing tube and moved to recovery in stable condition.
